title: How a new perspective can help you play better - By a challenger coach

replies.body:
I agree with this, however i think this mentality should translate to champion mastery as well (because champion mastery IS about improving, not winning)
for example the picture included, was one game i had, i got S+ and tons of kills, i got lots of objectives and felt like i was instrumental in team fights, anyway i like to think i did well with that champ, however i only got 289 champion points for it because we lost, however you get 1000+ points for a win regardless of your performance, (i have gotten C and won before and received higher scores than when i get S+ and lose)
so it is my belief that what is posted here is a mentality that should be applied to champion mastery. 

i believe that if you do really well with a champ but you lose, you should get more points than doing really badly but get carried by Yi and win.

Champion mastery is worthless, it just shows if you are competent with a certain list of champions because you played them after like April or something. 

Who cares about what score you get?

People who have all the champions and so IP is worthless and want something to work for?
also its fun using the emote

A good read and something to think on, I feel like it's really important as a player to take a minute after a game, ranked or normal, and think back on what you've done well or poorly. You needn't go over an entire replay of the game, but merely reflect on the memorable mistakes or successes.

Even just doing this, accepting that maybe you were out of position leading into a teamfight, or you shouldn't have been lurking around the enemy jungle with mid missing, will lead to positive growth.

No you won't instantly make better plays the next game, but you'll have learned, and this learning leads to climbing the ladder in a much more sustainable way than just a lucky winning streak.

I like this philosophy. Don't focus on "Win," focus on "learn and improve." One has you focused on this game, while the other is focused on the games ahead. Definitely something I'll try to take with me.
And I just started to make a series on learning/getting better too.
